review.title: Automatic Disambiguation of French Discourse Connectives
review.abstract: Discourse connectives (e.g. however, because) are terms that can explicitly convey a discourse relation within a text. While discourse connectives have been shown to be an effective clue to automatically identify discourse relations, they are not always used to convey such relations, thus they should first be disambiguated between discourse-usage non-discourse-usage. In this paper, we investigate the applicability of features proposed for the disambiguation of English discourse connectives for French. Our results with the French Discourse Treebank (FDTB) show that syntactic and lexical features developed for English texts are as effective for French and allow the disambiguation of French discourse connectives with an accuracy of 94.2%.

sections.heading: 3.1 Corpus
sections.text: To evaluate the disambiguization of the French discourse connectors, we used the French discourse link Treebank (FDTB) [6], which is the largest publicly accessible discourse corpus in French. [1] The corpus contains the note of more than 10K connectors used in discourse use in the French Treebank corpus [23]. FDTB uses the French discourse links of the LEXCONN resource [23], a lexicon of 328 French discourse connectors (e.g. "alors que") and their morphological variations (e.g. "alors qu"). Of the 328 discourse links listed in LEXCONN, 88 connectors appeared in the FDTB. For training and testing, we used the commented discourse connectors of the FDTB as positive instances and all other discourse links of the DDTB connectors that were not commented on as negative instances.

sections.heading: 3.3 Features
sections.text: As mentioned in Section 2, Pitler and Nenkova [20] have shown that the context of the discourse connections in the syntactic tree is very discriminatory for the disambigualization of the English discourse connections. They proposed four syntactical features: 1. SelfCat: The highest node in the discourse tree that includes the connecting words, but nothing more.2. SelfCatParent: The parent of the SelfCat. 3. SelfCatLeftSibling: The left sibling of the SelfCat. 4. SelfCatSightSibling: The right sibling of the SelfCat. sections.heading: 3.4 Data Preparation
sections.text: Although the work focuses on the disambigualization of French discourse connectors, we also conducted the same experiments with English discourse connectors, which allowed us to better analyze the results and compare the performance of our model in French and English. For our experiments, we used the FDTB and the PDTB corpora to note the gold discourse for French and English texts, respectively. We also used the French treebank (FTB) [1] and the Penn treebank (PTB) [15] to preserve the parse trees of French and English texts. 6 The parse tree is the French treebank. To prepare the FDTB for our experiments, we used the French treebank (FTB) [1] to preserve the syntactic trees of the FDTB sets. sections.heading: 4.1 Results
sections.text: Similar to Pitler and Nenkova [20], we report results with a maximum entropy classifier that uses ten-fold cross-validation of the extracted data sets. We used the standard implementation of the maximum entropy classifier available in WEKA [9] for our experiments. Table 5 shows the overall performance of the classifier for disambiguating French and English discourse connectives. Results show that the classifier can distinguish between discourse use and non-discourse use of French discourse connectors with an accuracy of 94.2% and a measurement of 86.2%, which is close to the results for English discourse connectives on the PDTB (accuracy of 93.6% and F-score of 88.9%).

sections.heading: 4.2 Feature Analysis
sections.text: To evaluate the contribution of each feature, we ranked the features based on their information gain for both languages. As Table 6 shows, the syntactic features with our datasets provide less information about discourse use or non-discourse use for French discourse combinations than for English. This seems to indicate that English discourse combinations tend to appear in more limited syntactical contexts than French discourse combinations. We also experimented with other combinations of features. We ranked the features based on their information gain and added one feature each. Table 7 shows the accuracy of the classifier for each subset of features for French discourse combinations. The differences between the accuracy features were evaluated using the Student-t test, with P < 0.05. Statistically significant increases are marked with the table, while a lack of significant increase in connectivity features is only reported with a total of 8statistical features.

sections.heading: 4.3 Per-Connective Analysis
sections.text: The overall results of Table 5 showed that the characteristics proposed for English can also have precisely disambiguous French discourse connectibles. However, if we analyze the results for each connective trait, many connectives appear to be very well classified with the characteristics used; while some of them are more difficult to disambiguate. If we take as a starting point the assignment of the most likely class based solely on the Conn tract, many connectives receive statistically significant improvements with the classifier that has learned about the proposed characteristics. Table 8 shows the accuracy of the classifier for the French discourse connectibles that have achieved the greatest improvements over the baseline. sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: In this paper, we have examined the applicability of the syntactical and lexical characteristics that Pitler and Nenkova [20] propose for the disambiguation of English discourse connectibles to French. Our experiments at the French Discourse Bank (FDTB) show that, although the syntactic characteristics 7 are almost as effective for French and Arabic discourse connectibles, discourse connectibles that occur less than 20 times are not taken into account. [4] The fact that the local syntactic characteristics proposed for English can be used almost as effectively for French and Arabic discourse connectivities suggests that lexicalized discourse connectivities effectively differentiate between discourse use and non-discourse use, as well as between French and English discourse habits.
